questions.question:
Question 1: Which of the following is the most powerful example of social cohesion in social 
organisation?
questions.explanation: The most powerful example of social cohesion in social organization is the family. It is the most basic and primary unit in all societies.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is an unstable and emotional temporary social group with a leader?
questions.explanation:
A mob is an unstable and emotional temporary social group with a leader. Temporary social groups can be classified into: • Crowd- It is a temporary group motivated by a common interest or curiosity. It lacks an internal 
organization and has no leader. • Mob- It is a crowd with a leader, and is more emotional than a crowd. It is unstable and has no 
internal organization. • Herd- This social group has a leader and the members have to follow his/her orders without 
question. A band is a permanent spatial group that constitutes a few families living together. Other 
permanent spatial groups are villages, cities, towns and the state.

questions.question: Question 3: What is the correct order of a family cycle?

options.a: Formation, extension, complete extension, dissolution, contraction, complete contraction
options.b: Formation,contraction,extension, complete extension, dissolution, complete dissolution
options.c: Formation, contraction, complete contraction, extension, complete extension, dissolution
options.d: Formation, extension, complete extension, contraction, complete contraction, dissolution

questions.explanation:
The order of the family cycle is formation, extension, complete extension, contraction, complete 
contraction and dissolution.

questions.question: Question 4: What are the constituents of a nuclear family?

options.a: Father, mother, son and his wife
options.b: Husband, wife and 4 year old daughter
options.c: Husband and wife only, without their children

questions.explanation: A nuclear family consists of a married couple and their children when they are dependant. They are also called elementary families.

questions.question:
Question 6: In urbanized and industrialized countries, occupation is a major determinant of all of the 
following except:
questions.explanation: Occupation is not a determinant of community participation. Occupation in most urbanized and industrialized communities is a major determinant of: • Economic rewards • Extent of authority • Extent of obligations • Degree of status • Values and lifestyles

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is not a limitation of classifying social class according to occupation?

options.b: Inequality between men and women in same jobs

questions.explanation:
Most classifications of social class based on occupational take skills into consideration. Occupation is a useful measure of social differentiation particularly in communities highly 
industrialised and urbanized. Limitations of cccupational classification of social class: • Heterogenous grouping- occupations grouped together are not usually related to each other • Occupational mobility- occupations practiced by the members of a social class as well as the 
perception of a certain occupation in the hierarchy may change over a period of time • Gender biases- the same occupation may be considered as belonging to a superior class for men 
as compared to women 522 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: èou are tasked with conducting a health and wellness survey of the employees of your 
hospital. Which of the following scales will you not use to classify their socio-economic 
statuses?
questions.explanation:
Likert scale is not a scale used for socio-economic status (SES). It is a psychometric scale used to 
understand the attitude of people from their responses. It is a scale widely used in 
questionnaire-based research. Scales that have been used for SES are: • Udai Pareek scale • ‘uppuswamy scale • Radhukar scale • Jalota scale • Shirvastava scale • Bharadwaj scale • ‘ulshestra scale • Hollingshead scale.

questions.question:
Question 9: As a part of a community health survey team, you interview 50 families from a nearby village 
in your district. Which of the following scales would you use to classify the socio-economic 
statuses of these families?
questions.explanation: The Uday Pareek scale is used for the classification of socio-economic status in rural areas.

questions.question:
Question 10: Which of the following components are included under the modified ‘uppuswamy scale for 
socio-economic status ?
questions.explanation:
The modified ‘uppuswamy scale uses income of the family, education and occupation of head of 
family.

questions.question:
Question 12: In the doctor-patient relationship, which of the following is not a level of communication? 516 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Communication on a psychological plane is not a level of communication in a doctor-patient 
relationship. For a successful doctor-patient relationship, a doctor must have in his/her regard communication 
on the following levels: • Communication on an emotional plane: To build rapport, ensure openness and incite trust from 
the patient. • Communication on a cultural plane: To understand the community to which the patient belongs, 
his/her cultural factors that may influence health and disease and also for economic 
understanding of the patient. • Communication on an intellectual plane: To give adequate explanation for their conditions and 
help the patients develop insight into their ailments.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is the best suited role for a medical social worker?

options.b: Designing coping strategies, interviewing and case work

questions.explanation:
A medical social worker is a person who is trained mainly in social work and interviewing. He/she carries out duties that augment public and community healthcare by way of identifying, 
understanding and relaying important information about a patient’s determinants of health. They are not involved in active treatment, prescribing or providing economic support.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following practices is covered under the COPRA act?
questions.explanation:
Consumer Protection Act or COPRA was instituted in 1986 and deals with consumer rights. It recognizes six rights of the consumers, which are: • Right to safety • Right to be informed • Right to be heard • Right to choose • Right to seek redressal 524 
Sold by @itachibot • Right to consumer education

questions.question:
Question 15: Which of the following is used to describe an interview used to note the gradual influence of 
some social or psychological process?
questions.explanation:
A repetitive interview is used to note the gradual influence of some social or psychological 
process. A record is maintained to understand the changes. Interviews are methods used widely in investigations and in research. A proper interview 
technique must be employed to achieve the objective. Aims of an interview: • To secure information usually through face to face association and to understand the 
individual/group being interviewed. • To form a hypothesis. • To collect personal data for quantitative purposes. • To collect data from secondary sources of information. Types of interviews: • A direct or structured interview consists of predetermined questions and sequence. • A non-directive or unstructured interview doesn’t have any sequence of questions set 
beforehand. The interviewer listens and allows the speaker to narrate his/her own experiences or 
opinions. • A focused interview is usually used to study effects of mass communication like radio broadcasts 
or film. In this, the interviewer/researcher focuses on a particular aspect on the problem and 
draws responses from people. • A repetitive interview is used to note the gradual influence of some social or psychological 
process. A record is maintained to understand the changes.

questions.question:
Question 17: What is the application of scientific methods to investigate the study of complex human 
organizations, services and management called?
questions.explanation:
Operational research is the application of scientific methods of investigation to study complex 
human organizations, services and management. Pure research is also called fundamental research or basic research. It is aimed at improving 
scientific theories or understanding of them. Applied research is a methodology used for a specific, practical problem like diseases or business. 
It involves the practical application of science.

questions.question: Question 18: What was the purpose of setting up the Nirbhaya Fund?

options.d: Providing free medical care for women

questions.explanation: The Nirbhaya Fund was set up by the government of India for promoting the safety of women.

questions.question: Question 19: Choose the correct match.

options.a: Gross Domestic Product- gross income generated only from within the country
options.b: Gross National Product- gross domestic product minus the depreciation on a country’s capital
options.c: Net National Product- income generated from within the country and income received from
options.d: Net Domestic Product- market value of all final goods and services in a country during a year

questions.explanation:
Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is the income generated only from within the country and does not 
include income received from abroad.

Question 20: 518

questions.explanation:
The total public health expenditure is around 1.25% percentage of India's GDP (National Health 
Profile 2020 report). The National Health Policy, 2017 states the aim to increase this to around 2.5% by 2025.

questions.question:
Question 21: A mother brings her 4-year-old boy for a well-baby check-up. Upon examination the 
paediatrician diagnoses her son with hidden hunger. What is meant by the term hidden 
hunger?

options.a: Child's diet is deficient in carbohydrates
options.c: Child is taking a diet that is deficient in essential amino acids
options.d: Child suffers from deficiency of omega 3 fatty acids

questions.explanation:
Hidden hunger refers to micronutrient deficiency. It occurs when there is deficiency in intake or 
absorption of micronutrients like vitamins, iron, zinc, etc. The health effects of these deficiencies are less obvious or invisible and thus referred to as hidden 
hunger. The consequences of hidden hunger are seen in all ages. 526 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 22: Which of the following statements is correct with regards to the estimation of poverty line?

options.a: Per capita expenditure of Rs. 32 per day in urban areas
options.b: Per capita expenditure of Rs. 47 per day in rural areas
options.c: Daily calorie intake of 2100 calories in urban areas
options.d: Daily calorie intake of 2700 calories in rural areas

questions.explanation:
An estimate of the poverty line is the expenditure required for a daily calorie intake of 2100 in 
urban areas and 2400 in rural areas, per person. Income-based poverty line in India is per capita expenditure of Rs. 47 in urban areas and Rs. 32 
in rural areas per day.

questions.question: Question 23: Which of the following legislations does not offer social security for industrial workers?
questions.explanation:
The Labour Charter Act does not offer social security for industrial workers. Social security is the security that society furnishes through appropriate organization, against 
certain risks to which its members are exposed. These risks include sickness, maternity, old age 
and death. Social security for industrial workers is given by: • Workmen’s Compensation Act • The Family Pension Scheme • Central Maternity Benefit Act • Employees’ State Insurance Act Social security for civil servants is given by governments in the form of pension, gratuity, 
provident fund, etc. The Central Government Health Scheme provides security to employees of 
the Central Government. Insurance schemes from the likes of Life Insurance Corporation of India, etc. have security 
schemes for the general public.

questions.question:
Question 24: 519 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is not a component of the global hunger index (GHI)?
questions.explanation:
The infant mortality rate is not a component of the global hunger index. The Global Hunger Index (GHI) has three dimensions. These dimensions are measured 
by indicators. GHI score = (1/3 X standardized PUN) + (1/6 X standardised CWA) + (1/6 X standardised CST) + 
(1/3 X Standardised CM) Where, • PUN is the proportion of the population that is undernourished • CWA is the prevalence of wasting in children under 5 years of age • CST is the prevalence of stunting in children under 5 years of age 527 
Sold by @itachibot • CM is the proportion of children dying under the age of 5 years of age. The result lies on a scale from 0 to 100, with 0 meaning no hunger and 100 being the worst score. 
The GHI is given by the International Food Policy Research Institute. In 2021, India's GHI was 
27.5. It ranks 101 among 116 countries. In the 2022,India's GHI stands at 29.1, and India 
ranks 107th out of the 121 countries. Dimensions
